Question: Which of these is found in all organisms?

Choices:
A: a cell
B: a tissue
C: an organ
D: an organ system
steps: First, we assess the meaning of each choice in the context of all living organisms.
A cell (Choice A) is the basic structural and functional unit of life; all living organisms are composed of one or more cells, including unicellular (single-celled) organisms like bacteria.
A tissue (Choice B) is a group of similar cells that perform a specific function. Tissues are found in multicellular organisms but not in unicellular ones.
An organ (Choice C) is a structure composed of different types of tissues working together. Organs are only present in multicellular organisms.
An organ system (Choice D) is a group of organs that work together for a common purpose. This applies only to multicellular organisms and not to unicellular ones.
Since only A: a cell is found in all organisms, regardless of whether they are unicellular or multicellular, it is the only choice that fits the requirement.
